segments.text: Listen.
That's me.
Here I am.
This is October 17, I believe.
That's right.
And sitting in the Engineering Physics Building, talking with the Dean Emeritus of Engineering, Robert H. H?
H, as in Henry.
Robert H. Page.
Bob, to begin with, to introduce yourself to anyone that might listen to this tape or
read the transcription, describe your background before you came to A&M.
Where did you grow up?
What did your family do?
Where did you go to high school and then college?
Okay.
Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, city of brotherly love.
And I was fortunate.
I went to a high school that was competitive, Danner, the Central High School, one of those prestigious high schools that had something in common with the Alamo, both 1836.
And it also is the only high school in the nation that has degree-granting authority.
See, in 1836, there weren't too many colleges around.
The state of Pennsylvania kind of referred to it as the people's college.
They gave them the authority.
They never took it away.
But it's not for all students.
But anyway, I graduated from high school.
I graduated in January 1945.
And at that time, of course, there was a war going on.
And there were mid-year classes.
Like all my other 17-year-olds, we all enlisted before graduation.
And I was very fortunate that I took all these Army general classification tests and got sent to VMI for their Army Specialized Training Reserve Program.
Spent one year there, which was the maximum you could spend, and that was equivalent to two years of college I found later.
But anyway, after that I went on active duty and traveled all around the USA.
Finally went over to Hawaii where I was chief engineer of an armed forces radio service station in Hawaii, station KRHO.
And then we were starting to get discharged by then.
The war in Europe was over.
The war in Japan was over.
And I came back to the USA and tried to get into a university.
But as everyone will recall, after World War II, that was very difficult.

So I kept going west from Philadelphia, ended up at Ohio University, and in two years finished up my bachelor's in mechanical engineering there, then headed further west to University of Illinois and got a master's and Ph.D.
So that was all the academic training.
I did a little teaching at Illinois.
But then I went into industry with ESSO, now called Exxon, ESSO Research and Engineering Company on the East Coast.
And while I was there, I started teaching graduate courses at night at Stevens Institute, also on the East Coast in Hoboken, New Jersey.
And then Stevens Institute recruited me to come full time.
So I left the private world there and went to Stevens and stayed there four years before Rutgers University recruited me as a department head.
When was that?
New Brunswick, New Jersey.
That was 1961.
And I served as department head for mechanical engineering.
It expanded.
It became mechanical and nuclear, mechanical, nuclear, and aerospace as things grew.
And finally then, after 15 years of that, I thought I'd do something different.
So I stepped out of the department head's job.
and was doing some research.
I was very fortunate.
I had a contract from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research, and they gave them all crazy names.
This was called a Themis program, which made Themis, a Greek name, T-H-E-M-I-S.
And that was one of those programs that during the 70s, certain students didn't like, but nevertheless, it was a good program.
Brought in about a million dollars in research.
But then, so things were going well, but then I got a very nice letter from Mac Prescott saying that I had been nominated for the dean's job here, and he explained a lot about the dean's job.
Now, this is 70...
This would have been... 78, 79?
Do you have any idea who, how, forwarded your name?
I had no idea, no.
I think Mack indicated later that there was more than one.
But in fact, what I had to do right away after getting that nice letter was find out exactly where Texas A&M University was.
What did you learn about A&M in that research, in that inquiry?
Oh, well, what I did was I talked to a lot of people, and actually I only knew one person.
I only saw him once in a while at ASME, American Society of Mechanical Engineering, meetings, and that was George Thompson.
And George Thompson was well-known.
I could chat with him, but I didn't see him often enough to get a lot of information.

But I looked in all the usual reference books, talked to people at the National Science Foundation, and I was an officer in the accreditation program so I could look up and see how A&M was doing that way.
So the best thing to do was to accept the challenge and come down and see what it was all about.
So that turned out to be very nice because I was impressed with Mac Prescott right away.
describe the search process as you would call it.
The search process.
I was contacted and then I did a little study, wrote a letter back and said I'd like to find out more and I came down and Mac met me at the airport and
Then there was a group of, there was a search committee that I met with and got shown around a lot.
Did the search process, as far as you recall, was it, did it end up being a positive?
Did it increase your interest or was the process not well done?
Oh, I think it was very well done, yeah.
I think it was very well done.
They had some good faculty on the search team.
Most of them aren't here anymore, but they did a good job.
What were your key concerns?
Well, my key concerns was where was the College of Engineering going?
And I had a little bit of a feeling that it was kind of standing still in the world as it existed at that time, because the...
Actually the faculty weren't well known outside the state of Texas and I found that by talking to people in other disciplines as well.
And that's not because they didn't visit outside but because they weren't publishing or getting any sort of national reputation that way.
So there were some but it wasn't by any means even a small.
minority doing that.
So I was concerned where they were going and what kind of resources were available and facilities and so forth.
And Mac Prescott was very honest with me.
He pointed out that there were challenges, that things weren't in as good shape as they really should be.
The graduate school operation in engineering was not really growing.
There was a shortage of space for operations and that it would be a challenge.
Well, actually that sort of interested me because I always liked challenges rather than having them come if it was a nice smooth job and I would just take care of things.
So that went well, and after that, we went back and thought about it some more, and then got an invitation to bring my wife down as well, bring Lola down, and we looked around again.
We checked some things in town, you know, churches and stores and things like that, and it looked good to us.
What was your candid impression of Bryan College Station?
I thought it was a nice, friendly town.
And, of course, we noticed at that time, we noticed that everything closed up early.
Nothing stayed open late at night or anything like that.
By late at night, I mean after 6 p.m.
But then the next thing was I got a call from Jarvis Miller.
Of course, I had met Jarvis during my visits, and he made the offer to me to come down, and I accepted the offer.
And what was that beginning salary?
The beginning salary was $61,500 per year.
What did that seem like to you at that time?
Actually, I was coming from my rather well-paid university.
Rutgers University has always been in the top class, and I was in what they call a professor two category.
So it seemed reasonable.
It wasn't an increase for me or anything like that.
Did anybody give you any directions or advice?
set any goals for you as you first got here?
I think a goal that stuck in my mind the most, number one, was what Mac Prescott kept impressing, and that was quality.
And every time I talked with him, he, quality, quality.
And that was the way I felt about it, too.
So that was number one.

The other goal, when I talked to Jarvis Miller, the president, from what I had seen, I thought a goal was to try to get a better management operation for the College of Engineering because the faculty were

answering to two bosses one being the dean on the academic side and one being a uh... experiment station on the other side both bosses controlled their salaries and so forth so it didn't seem to me like the best management so i talked to jarvis miller about that and he thought well that probably could be done but uh... it took time to get that done now at rutgers
You didn't have the separate experiment station?
We did not have a separate experiment station like that, no.
In terms of reporting responsibility, you reported to Mike Prescott.
That's correct.
As you arrived, describe the leadership staff that you inherited in engineering.
Who were the key people?
Well, actually, the former dean, Dean Benson, had moved out of the position, and there was someone just filling in whose name I don't recall.
Things had been just sort of kept the doors open, broach.
And there was no associate dean, which meant I had to find one quickly.
And then the others in the game then were...
not of the caliber I would like to see in those positions.
What about office staff?
The office staff brought in a new secretary for me who didn't have too much experience.
It would have been better if I had someone that knew how to play the games and handle the paperwork, but she worked out all right.
There was a fairly large office staff and they got the jobs done.
And you all were located
They were all located in the Zachry building in one office up there where my office was a room off of that, yes.
Was that physical space adequate?
It wasn't really, no, and it was sort of what people like to call a bullpen.
There were no dividers that separated one from another, so it was just sort of a wide open space but not open enough because there wasn't enough room and they were into each other, their desks.
How did you and your wife become acquainted with Texas A&M and Bryan College Station and Texas things, Aggie things?
Well, that worked out very well for us.
We seemed to really enjoy it.
And we were often asked the question, well, was it hard to move from New Jersey to Texas?
And we said, not difficult at all.
But nobody could move from Texas to New Jersey.
They had been here a long time.
Were there any people that now in hindsight you realize were very helpful, particularly helpful to you as a newcomer?

Oh, well, certainly Glenn Phillips was very helpful, and people like John Calhoun I had known through the American Society for Engineering Education, very helpful, but it seemed like no one gave us any problems, and we were
We had help from a lot of people when we moved here.
And you began your service on when?
I think the technical date was August the 1st, 1979.
And describe the College of Engineering.
Where was it physically?
What was where?
Well, the college itself was primarily in the Zachry building.
Most of the operations were there.
But the complication was with the experiment station.
It was hard to see where the line was drawn because most of the faculty, over half of them at that time, had appointments for their salary, part of their salary in the experiment station.
Well we had a separate civil engineering building and of course many of the buildings you see today weren't even here.
But the one I, it was interesting because when I really got busy and started to study the space situation,
the space for the academic operations had decreased over the last four years and the space for the T's and TTI operations had increased so the net effect looked like engineering was getting more.
But what I had a strong interest in was to make sure that academic was holding up and they were going down.
Did you set any goals for yourself?
Well, I did.
I wanted to
see some things improve right away.
I didn't know how long it would take.
But quite frankly, the computing situation was not up to the standard it should have been that I had known in other universities by inspecting them, accreditation visits and so forth.
So that was one high goal.
I wanted to see us get some fellowships to support graduate students, too, so the graduate program could roll.
and to get more interest in general from the faculty about graduate studies and things of that sort.
So those were really my primary goals and to try then to get A&M College of Engineering more on the map so it's more recognized.
As you learned more about the programs here,
compared to programs elsewhere?
What were the strongest programs here and then at the other extreme, which were the least strong?
Well, the strongest, with no question, was the civil engineering program.
And Donald McDonald was the department head at the same time.
He had good faculty.
They were very productive.
doing a good job all around.
When I reviewed department heads during my tenure as dean, I visited every person in the department in their office.
I wanted to see how they were doing.
I didn't want to drag them over to my office.
And when I visited for his review, it was no question that it was a first-class operation from the department head on down.
So it was the strongest, no question.
I think it's hard to say who was really the weakest, but electrical engineering could have used a lot more help to get straightened out.
I didn't realize until later that there were some problems there.

the uh... one time the department head hadn't taught a course for I don't know how many years you know fifteen or twenty years and wasn't really into it that way at all and so uh... petroleum engineering normally well petroleum engineering as you know
It has a special position that there are very few petroleum engineering departments and they're always rating number one or number two or something like that.
Then you take a program like mechanical engineering that might come in eighteen and it doesn't look good but there's two hundred and some out there.
Were there any program vacancies?
Was there anything that the College of Engineering at A&M didn't, any program we didn't have that you thought we should?
Well, that was pretty obvious.
They didn't have anybody really putting emphasis on computing at that time.
So I decided, and it took a long time, that we should have a computer science department.
And that took about four years or so to get it through the state board and all get approval.
But that was the main thing.
Then the other thing that worried me, to be quite honest, was I thought some of the programs were too large, including mechanical engineering.
When you have 50 faculty or so and they don't know each other,

It seemed large and I did toy with an idea that maybe mechanical should be split and Arrow had a group interested in mechanics and have those people that are doing the mechanic side of it, the material side of it, make a separate group for them, but I never carried that out.
But it still bothered me that the departments were so large I could talk to a faculty member and they didn't know other faculty members.
When you arrived, the total enrollment in engineering was about what?
Oh, man, I looked up those numbers the other day.
Compared to now?
Compared to now, shall I say.
It's amazing how high they were.
When I arrived, it was 8,070.

and in nineteen uh... eighty two eighty three just before uh... i had four years as dean was eleven thousand nine hundred and six now that's more than we have today and of course we had a much smaller faculty and much less space but uh... well the faculty were overloaded no question about it
And it went up even a little bit that way.
So the four year change from 78 to just 82 was a 48% increase without a faculty increase like that.
Looking at all your years here, compare your impression of Aggie engineering students to those you had known in New Jersey.
Well, that's hard to say because time makes a big difference when you start talking about students.

And probably most people my age that have looked at the situation would say in a lot of ways today's student is not as well prepared coming out of high school as they were, say, 10 years ago or something like that.
No, but I'm meaning when you first got here.
Oh, when I first got here, yeah.
The Aggies were dedicated.
And I talked to an awful lot of young men, mainly young men then because we didn't have many women in the program.
but a few women too that had been hoping to go to A&M since they were kids.
And they wanted to get the most out of it.
And I always think that's the best recipe for success in college.
They would try hard while they were here.
So that impressed me quite a bit.
The students that I had back at Rutgers as a department head, they weren't that dedicated.
But they were good students too, yeah.
Did you have more coeds up there than here?
Yeah, because we probably started pressing it earlier to try to get up to 15% or so in female.
That was kind of the goal or objective.
And did we have fewer minorities here?
We had fewer minorities here at first, yeah.
Experiment Station.
Who headed the Engineering Experiment Station when you arrived?
I'm trying to think of the gentleman's name at first.
He was just here a very short time.
He'd been here forever.
I say forever, but I can't think of his name.
But shortly after that, Porter.
Skip Porter became head of the Experiment Station.
Describe relations between the dean and the director.
I'd say they weren't too good because the problem was that the experiment station was just interested in bringing in research that would help the experiment station.
Their goal was more dollars, and the dean's was quality in the academic program.
So the relationship was a problem, and I know one of the problems was when it came to promotion and tenure and things like that.
And it took a while to get that straightened out, but finally the chancellor changed also during my time as dean, and Art Hanson came in.
He made it quite clear that it was the university's responsibility, the academic side, to decide on things like promotion and tenure.
All right.
Let's talk about this, because this is an important matter.
During your time as dean, who initiated
primarily, who initiated the employment of a new person?
Was it the Experiment Station or the College of Engineering?
Or both?
That's a good question.
Both.
Both, yeah.
Do you remember some that the Experiment Station hired that the College of Engineering didn't want?
Oh, they could easily do that.
Is that right?
Yeah, they could easily do that.
And did you all hire some?
Because they had people working 100% for them.
Okay.
Were there some faculty members that they wouldn't support at all?
I didn't know that, but as I said, when I looked at the records, there were well over half of the College of Engineering faculty that were supported by the Experiment Station.
You said promotions.
Sometimes give some examples without being specific by name.
Give some examples of some of the awkwardness.

I think there was a difference in the way the quality of the individual was measured and when it came to promotions, when it came to the final step after the department head had done his work, I met with the dean, with me, and with the head of the experiment station and also usually the head of the Texas Transportation Institute and anyone else that might be appropriate and we talked about each individual.
But again, it was that the academic viewpoint was different than the others.
And it wouldn't matter what an individual was doing as far as teaching and encouraging students and so forth.
If he was bringing in lots of money from the experiment station, they want to move that person ahead.
So that's where the squabbles really came up.
And these individuals
were housed quite often in adjoining offices, some who were primarily Experiment Station.
Oh yeah, definitely.
And so they picked up their mail near each other and so forth.
Normally, who initiated a proposal for promotion and rank?
That would be the department head, but the department head's salary is half on the experiment.
Every department head was paid by the experiment station as well.
While you were dean, if the department heads had had to make a choice, do you think they would have voted pro-college or pro- That would be a real guess, but I know that the
Experiment Station could, since they had something to say about the salary, they could make salary increases for the department head.
The department heads knew that without going to the dean.
And there were a few also who were engineering extension service.
Oh, yes.
Very few.
Now, that was Jim Bradley?
That's right.
Describe working with Jim.
No problem.
No problem with Jim?
No.
And Charlie Wooten, no problem.
Because I have coffee with Jim every other Saturday or so at Shipley, so I see him.
Interviewed Charlie Wooten not long ago.
Let's see, he's got a health problem right now.
Oh, he does?
I'm sorry to hear that.
Yeah.
What is it?
Because I believe he's getting ready to go through radiation.
He looked thinner than I had remembered.
Let's talk about this matter then in theory.
If you could have created the organizational structure, how do you think A&M then could have best been organized in engineering?
Well, if I had anything to say about the organizational structure, which I talked to Jarvis Miller about and Mac Prescott, it's obvious that there has to be a dean that's in charge of both

research and teaching and any other ideas closely related to that because my theory always has been and it's usually worked is that the best teachers are scholars or researchers that love to teach but just being scholars or researchers is not enough and just loving to teach is not enough either it's got to be that combination.
Is that normally the pattern at other land-grant schools that you know of?
Oh, I think so, yeah.
In fact, a lot of people thought it was very strange when they heard of the system that we had here where we had two bosses.
And so many faculty members said to me personally, they said, this is a strange system.
I have two people I have to report to.
I know that during...
the year that you and I served together, I know that that was one of the pulls and tugs in engineering and agriculture.
Were you aware, as we got into 1980, were you aware that there was approaching a crisis where Jarvis was advocating the structure that you wanted?
Were you aware that there was a crisis coming?
No, I would not.
None at all.
In fact, I was, I think, out of town in June of 80 when the secretary, my secretary called me and said, I want you to be informed that Jarvis Miller is being reassigned.
How did she learn?
I don't know.
Did someone call her?
I don't know.
I heard a story once which might be true.
In fact, you might have even told me this, that things are being confidential at A&M means you only tell one person at a time.
There you go.
I learned about it the night that we arrived in El Paso to begin my new task.
Mac had called the...
motel where we were spending the night, but I didn't get the message till 10.30 mountain time.
So I didn't, I was going to wait till the next morning, because it would have been 11.30 here, and by 7 o'clock mountain time, three reporters had called me.
to ask for comments.
During this first year with Prescott and Jarvis, can you give some examples of their positive support and encouragement?
Oh, well, I always felt that Mack thought that was the way to go.
Mac Prescott, and Jarvis seemed to go along with it.
In fact, I was very optimistic that Jarvis was going to make sure that got done.
Did you and the other deans talk about this much?
Not too much because they didn't have that problem.
Agriculture didn't have it as much as engineering?
Well they didn't indicate that it was a problem.
I knew faculty in agriculture but they seemed to be happy with their situation.
During the years that you were a dean
With which other deans did you have the closest relationship?
Probably business.
Business?
Yeah, because we had common problems.
We couldn't hire the faculty we want.
We didn't have the dollars we needed to hire.
Who was the business dean then?
Bill Mews.
Bill, who's now president at Auburn.
Right.
And deans met normally

well we had that uh... APC yeah the academic council or whatever it was called yeah academic program in the coke building yeah on monday uh monday right describe those meetings as you recall them oh they were very good meetings i i uh
You must have sat in on him.
Mac Prescott ran them.
I thought he did a good job.
He gave everybody a chance to talk that had anything to say.
In fact, his standard operating procedure was to go around the table and ask everybody by name.
He'd come to me, Bob, do you have anything to say?
And go right on around.
So I thought it worked very well, that system.
I was sorry to see it go when they changed the whole system.
How did, when Jarvis was reassigned and Chuck Sampson became the interim president, what did that mean for engineering?
Did anything change?
No.
I think Chuck Sampson was just minding the store.
And he knew all the department heads well for being here a long time.
And I was told that he wanted to be dean.
He reminded me he wasn't too happy about me being dean, but he was just minding his store.
All right, then Frank Vandiver came after him.
That's right.
So I had three presidents in four years and two chancellors.
Describe Vandiver's relationship with the Dean of Engineering.
Well, Vandiver was, from the minute he came, was very open.
I immediately invited him to come over and talk to the faculty, which he did.
And he was willing to talk to me about anything.
He was not going to fool around too much with the high-level politics, he said.
But I did point out the problems we had.
He agreed with me right from the start that we should get this organization straightened out.
In fact, he wrote a nice letter to the faculty at the time that we were going to finally get it straightened out.
At that time, he called in all the

TTI, Tease, myself, I'm trying to think who else was there, but into his office and said that he now saw that we should have a different organization for engineering and that probably the best way to carry it out was to start looking for a new super dean was the term he used and that was kicked around a lot in the media.
It was dropped after a while.
But that was one way of describing it.
But then he wrote a nice letter to the faculty, and I said, well, we've got to have a faculty meeting right away.
The faculty know, and he agreed to come to the faculty meeting, and then the provost agreed.
At that time, we had a provost.
We no longer had a vice president for academic affairs.
The provost agreed to come as well.
Was McDonald, by that time, was he the...
Chief academic officer or was that Mack Prescott?
Mack Prescott.
But I'm trying to think, what was the timing on that?
I know Eaton had taken over as provost before.
In fact, Mack decided that it was time to, with all these presidents changing, to move out.
Now, you mentioned Chancellor Hanson.
Yeah.
He was an engineer.
Right.
Did you know him before he came here?
Yes, I did.
I didn't know him very well, but I knew of him.
I had one of his books.
He wrote an engineering book.
He's probably still sitting over there.
And, of course, I talked to him about the situation also, and he said he couldn't understand why it was organized that way.
That's when he's sitting in the chancellor's seat.
He said...
I told, I guess he said I told Frank Vanderveer, these are not the exact words, but the idea that I'm amazed he could hire a dean under that situation.
that it had to be direct control.
It couldn't be having one person serve two masters all the time with different objectives.
All right.
Did they move then to make the change?
Yes, they did.
That helped it along.
I think then after Art Hanson had talked to me about that, I think then he must have talked to Frank.
That's because the time schedule seemed to be such that then Frank called the meeting and we went ahead.
And so that change came in...
In the summer of 83, you know.
Okay.
During your period of service, describe what you are most proud of having accomplished.
Oh, boy.
Well, there was an awful lot, actually.
What I was most proud of...
I think I was proud that we got industry involved.
We started and we had industrial advisory committees for every department.
And I finally totaled them up once.
I think I had the number over here somewhere to how many we had.

it was rather impressive we had uh... two hundred seventy three people from industry serving directly on departmental advisories committee so we had that kind of interaction at first people said well you can't do that there's no industry in college station and brian i said well i wasn't thinking of college station and brian it's a big state so uh... we had i was proud of uh... that fact that we got uh... got those involved and then also uh...

another thing that uh... it turned out very well the college of engineering should have some sort of honors that they bestow on alumni of course the alumni association uh... former students were doing that but at a lower level so i initiated that where the faculty could make recommendations and we'd pick three or four maybe five each year and bring them in that turned out very well because for so many of them uh...

they were extremely good and we gave them the notoriety and publicity they moved up one up the line to key positions that has kept running very well over the years so that was good to get that external impact that way and all those people that came in actually we honored them but they continued to do a lot for us
worked out very well.
Sounds like a good investment.
Yeah, I think so.
And then I was proud of the fact that we really finally got the computer situation improved tremendously.
How'd you do that?
Well, it took time.
When I first came here there were some requests coming through and somebody asked me for my opinion of it and they were buying a lot of card program calculators
And these were things that punched the holes.
And it was a real bargain.
You could get them from IBM very cheap.
But I said, no, that mode is changing.
And there was a big fuss about that.
Actually, Jarvis Miller was concerned about computing.
I wrote him a couple of reports on that.
We finally got an up-to-date computer through some donations from Pat Zachary and other sources and got it right in the Zachary building.
There was another computer on campus that people weren't too happy with.
I think T's was controlling that, but the new computer was located in the Zachry building and faculty had access to it right away.
So that was just a step that got us moving that way, and then people started getting personal computers on their desks and things like that.
It was interesting, the first personal computer that was purchased, I bought in the dean's office.
And that was a job, to get it through the purchasing here and over at the state.
Why would anybody want a computer that sits on their desk?
They thought of them as big monsters somewhere.
But anyway, somebody had to break the ice there, I guess.
Do you have any idea what the investment cost was of that one?
Yeah, I do.
It was very low power compared to anything we had now, and it was about $6,000.
Let's see.
Did you make some appointments that you now think in hindsight were key appointments?
Some new faculty, some new... Well, I had to get an associate dean.
And so we went out and searched there.
We brought in a couple people.
And one of them was a person I had hired once before.
When I was at Rutgers as a department head, I had hired L.S.
Fletcher, Skip Fletcher.
But he had left Rutgers and gone to University of Virginia as department head.
He was well qualified for that position.
So he was one of the ones and we looked them all over and the offer was made to Skip Fletcher and that turned out very well.
He was a very good man.
And department heads?
He was an associate?
No, no, no.
Oh, as department heads?
Well, there wasn't, unfortunately, there wasn't much turnover in department heads.
during my period of time there.
As an administrator, if you could have it operated the way you wanted it, what would be the key role of a department head?
What would be their major task?
Well, that's a good question.
It's hard to say what the key role is, but I always thought the department had the interface between the faculty and the dean, obviously.

So the department head should let the dean know where things are standing as far as the teaching load on the faculty, the instrumentation that's needed, the facilities, and so forth, and have that all worked out in some detail and bring it forth to the dean.
Do you think the department head should feel automatically bound by a majority vote of the department?
No, I don't think he could progress then.
He or she, I should say, nowadays.
And how long should they serve?
Well, that's hard to say.
Every school's got different
ideas on how long they should term.
But the more I think about it, that's one reason I stopped being a department head.
I thought three five-year terms was long enough.
And I would say something like that maybe no longer than fifteen years or ten years.
Also, you're saying a term and they're reviewed every so many years.
That's right.
There should be a review, definitely.
Everybody should be reviewed.
Did, while you were dean, did y'all have any kind of highly publicized problems with tenure, promotion, termination?
No, we didn't have any big ones like that.
No lawsuits?
No lawsuits, no.
There was one where a person falsified information about previous degrees and things of that sort.
That was on our faculty already.
But that was so clear cut that in any court, if you give false information on your application to begin with of that sort.
Did that person's employment terminate?
That's right.
Let me...
In terms of...
exterior funding and so forth, were there some key accomplishments in engineering during your years as dean that you're proud to look back on?
Well, there were two.

is that uh... when i studied faculty salaries uh... after i came here and got all that detailed data compared it to average faculty salaries which i could get from several sources uh... both nationally and in this uh... region in the southwest region uh... we were way behind that meant that i went through the right channels to the uh... board of regents and asked for funds for that it didn't go over too well
So I thought about that a little bit more, and I talked to Bill Mews, and then the two of us went.
He was having the same problem.
He had made some studies.
He had data graphs just like I did where we could make our point clearly.
The data was there.
And then it was decided that there would be a special mid-year salary increase with some funds given to both deans.
And, of course, we'd have to make the allocations and so forth.

Well, I thought that was very important because it was very good for morale to bring the faculty up and since there were no special rules tied to that, somebody that was really productive and for some reason hadn't been acknowledged, he might end up with a ten percent or twelve percent increase and others got one or two percent, something like that.
You know, the usual mirth sort of thing.
So that was, I thought that was very important.
and a major step forward.
In those years, which similar programs in engineering were you watching most closely as your comparators?
You mean in other universities?
Probably University of Illinois because I had so many friends there that they could give me detailed data on things that are hard to get otherwise unless you have extremely good contacts.
But there were others and we started actually in sort of the Southwest Conference to circulate some information.
I started that on teaching loads and faculty and things of that sort.

But the other point that I made, which I was very proud of, and you can almost look out the windows and see, and you're sitting in one of them, is that I got the data on square feet per faculty member from other universities and made charts on that, and we were way beyond.
We just needed more space.
And our space, as I mentioned earlier to you, had decreased.
over the last four or five years because it was taken over by external operations, the T's and TTI and so forth.

So I had that data and I went in and talked to the Board of Regents about that and some of them didn't like it because they said they thought everything was great when the Zachry Building was completed.
They had been told that that would solve everything for engineering.
And I pointed out that when the Zachry building was completed, there were like 3,500 total students.
We have three times that right now.
So, of course, that wasn't too good either because they don't always like to be corrected on something like that.
